newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish PM denies military complaint on funding.
newsitem.headline: Turkish PM denies military complaint on funding.

text.p: Turkish Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan denied on Saturday military complaints that his cabinet was ignoring army demands for funds for operations against rebel Kurds, Anatolian news agency said.
"Any shortfall in meeting the needs of our army is out of question," the semi-official agency quoted Erbakan as saying.

General Erol Ozkasnak, a military spokesman, told reporters on Friday that the army had asked the government for funding of a cross-border operation against Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) rebels, but had received no answer.
Erbakan said he would gather finance ministry and military officials on Saturday to discuss the issue.

Ozkasnak said Kurdish rebels had used sophisticated anti-aircraft missiles to shoot down two army helicopters on a mission in northern Iraq -- a Cougar troop carrier with 11 officers and soldiers on board last week and a smaller Super-Cobra attack helicopter on May 18.
He said the PKK had for the first time gained access to such weaponry, from countries which Turkey accuses of supporting the rebels.

"Since 1992, the PKK has wanted to get hold of SA-7 missiles...We have informed the foreign ministry five times that primarily the governments of Iran, Syria, Armenia, Greece and Cyprus have been providing the terrorist organisation with these weapons," Ozkasnak said.
Erbakan said the finance ministry had released 60 percent of a 647-trillion-lira ($4.5 billion) annual budgetary fund, allocated for the defence ministry and the army, so far this year.
"This rate is far lower for other institutions," he said.
Erbakan said parliament must pass legislation to provide the army with extra funds.

Thousands of Turkish troops, backed by air power, poured into northern Iraq on May 14 in a big cross-border operation against bases of the PKK, fighting for independence or autonomy in southeast Turkey.
Turkey said the operation would continue until the rebel presence in the region was destroyed.
